p.s: Sonnet 138, written byShakespeare is about the paradox nature of love and truthfulness.
The speaker begins by introducing the guiding idea of the sonnet.
His or her lover is untruthful, though he or she ignores the lies willingly.
This is because his or her lover might imagine the speaker to the caught up in ungenuine pleasenties.
In the second quatrain this idea gets further developed.
The beloved knows that her lover is not of inexperienced youth, yet persuades herself into believing the opposite and is thus lying to herself.
However, the speaker does not intervene and lets the deceit play on.
At this point the speaker arrives at the general conclusion, that both of them are simoly denrins the truth.
In the third quatrain the train of thought abruptly change as the speaker asks himself why the both of them can notcannot simply tell their truths.
This is where the speaker establishes his or her thesis.
The essence of this seeming trust is what keeos the truth from coming out and is the foundation the love humans know best.
The speaker arrives at the moral of the story in the concluding couplet.
The couple will keep up with their untruthfulness and stay together.
